newsitem.title: USA: Senate charman vows industry-friendly mining bill.
newsitem.headline: Senate charman vows industry-friendly mining bill.

text.p: The chairman of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee said Wednesday he will introduce an industry-friendly mining reform bill to help head off more pro-environmental legislation backed by Democrats.

Sen. Frank Murkowski, an Alaska Republican, said he hopes to submit a mining reform bill to compete with a proposal likely to come from Sen. Dale Bumpers, an Arkansas Democrat and ardent environmentalist.

Although he predicted Bumpers' bill will not pass, Murkowski said in a speech at the Alaska Miners Association annual convention "we need to draft responsible legislation that takes an edge off their drastic and irresponsible legislation."

Murkowski said the retirement of Sen. Bennett Johnston, a Louisiana Democrat who was somewhat industry friendly, is likely to result in a more pro-environment policy among minority members of the Energy and Natural Resources Committee -- starting with Bumpers, who will become the ranking minority member.

Bumpers wants to impose an 8 percent royalty on hard-rock minerals taken from federal lands and to eliminate the patent provision that transfers ownership of federal lands to miners who have staked claims there, Murkowski said.
The target is the Mining Law of 1872, cherished by miners and attacked by environmentalists, U.S. Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt and many economists as an anacronism.
Under the 124-year-old law, miners pay no royalties for hard-rock minerals taken from federal lands. Miners also get to keep the land where their operations are located by filing claims there.
Babbitt and other critics of the law say miners should pay royalties for gold and other metals taken from federal lands, as extractors of oil and coal already do.

Murkowski said development supporters will have to soften their stances somewhat to be successful in the new Congress, even though Republicans widened their majority in the Senate and pro-development Alaskans kept control of key Senate and House committees.
"To some extent, we're going to have to take a defensive posture on some of our issues," he said at the miners' gathering.
